docs.abstract: Problem of Americans who lack health insurance has been debated endlessly for decade, yet ranks of the uninsured keep growing, now standing at 44.3 million, or 16 percent of population; Clinton administration tried and failed to solve problem with sweeping health care initiative in 1993-94, and issue promises to loom large in this year's presidential campaign; several reasons why reform defies best efforts of policymakers detailed; initiatives of Vice Pres Al Gore and Gov George W Bush, and their potential pitfalls, described; charts profile the uninsured (M)
docs.snippet: THE problem of Americans who lack health insurance has been debated endlessly for the last decade, yet theranks of the uninsured keep growing. Having risen by more than a million a year in the 1990's, the number of uninsured now stands at 44.3...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE problem of Americans who lack health insurance has been debated endlessly for the last decade, yet theranks of the uninsured keep growing. Having risen by more than a million a year in the 1990's, the number of uninsured now stands at 44.3 million - 16 percent of the population - even though the United States is enjoying the longest period of economic growth in its history.

headline.main: Still Uninsured, and Still a Campaign Issue

docs.abstract: Elin Schoen Brockman article on trends in birthing methods, from natural childbirth and water immersion to booking inductions and Caesarians months ahead of time; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: OF all the zingers uttered by my obstetrician, Alan DeCherney (known for his great delivery, in every sense of the word), the most memorable was when I told him that I thought I wanted to squat while giving birth. ''And what am I supposed to do?'' he...
docs.lead_paragraph: OF all the zingers uttered by my obstetrician, Alan DeCherney (known for his great delivery, in every sense of the word), the most memorable was when I told him that I thought I wanted to squat while giving birth. ''And what am I supposed to do?'' he demanded. ''Get down on the floor in a raincoat?'' The year was 1987. The hospital was Yale-New Haven. Note that I said hospital. As an elderly primagravida (loosely translated, a first-time mom-to-be who will be receiving mail from the AARP by the time her child is in middle school), my concern was not so much to experience childbirth as to survive it.

headline.main: The Baby and the Bathwater: Birth Methods Then and Now

docs.abstract: Thousands of brave, hopeful and sometimes desperate people with cancer and other diseases participate in medical trials in United States each year; such experiments can offer patients chance to try promising treatments not yet available to public but also are risky, since researchers do not know whether treatments will be safe or effective; Web sites for finding trials noted; photos (M)
docs.snippet: STANDING between millions of Americans and screening for colon cancer is the screening procedure itself: a blast of air into the rectum, followed by the insertion of an optical scope and 30 minutes or so of probing, all aided by continuous air...
docs.lead_paragraph: STANDING between millions of Americans and screening for colon cancer is the screening procedure itself: a blast of air into the rectum, followed by the insertion of an optical scope and 30 minutes or so of probing, all aided by continuous air pressure. But the exam, called a colonoscopy, unequivocally saves lives, because it allows doctors to detect and promptly remove polyps that might otherwise grow into cancerous tumors. As many as 96 percent of people who receive a diagnosis of colon cancer would survive at least five years if their malignancies were detected early, according to the National Cancer Institute.

headline.main: Making a Lifesaver Less of an Ordeal

docs.abstract: Already difficult question for menopausal women of whether to use hormone replacement therapy is being further complicated by research questioning notion that same-size dose fits all women, or even same woman over time (M)
docs.snippet: NOWADAYS, it seems as if only people with a Ph.D. in epidemiology -- and preferably circus experience -- can juggle all the pros and cons of hormone replacement therapy (H.R.T.), much less make sense of all the conflicting reports.    As if the...
docs.lead_paragraph: NOWADAYS, it seems as if only people with a Ph.D. in epidemiology -- and preferably circus experience -- can juggle all the pros and cons of hormone replacement therapy (H.R.T.), much less make sense of all the conflicting reports. As if the choices the treatment itself poses weren't complicated enough, now medical researchers are challenging the popular notion that the same-size dose fits all women. That means the million-dollar question facing women of menopausal age -- do I or don't I? -- may soon be eclipsed by an even trickier one: how much is right for me? The answer to the latter question could determine the response to the former, for dose has a direct bearing on the treatment's side effects, long-term safety and likely benefits.

headline.main: For Hormone Replacement Therapy, One High-Dose Size May Not Fit All

docs.snippet: LOOKING back, Alice Myhal says it was partly the doctor's enthusiasm that helped her decide: she sensed an energy level as high as her own in Dr. Beth Overmoyer, and it struck a chord. But religion had a role, too. Since providence had brought her to...
docs.lead_paragraph: LOOKING back, Alice Myhal says it was partly the doctor's enthusiasm that helped her decide: she sensed an energy level as high as her own in Dr. Beth Overmoyer, and it struck a chord. But religion had a role, too. Since providence had brought her to Dr. Overmoyer just in time for a new, experimental treatment, she thought she must be meant to try it.

headline.main: For Experimental Treatments, 'Somebody Has to Be First'

docs.abstract: Pediatricians are increasingly taking on responsiblity of addressing children's emotional and behavioral problems as well as their medical ones; photos (M)
docs.snippet: THERE is a barely perceptible, almost wistful, longing for the time when his practice largely consisted of curing childhood diseases. Measles, mumps, chicken pox -- these were definable ailments that would likely go away with proper treatment. Now,...
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is a barely perceptible, almost wistful, longing for the time when his practice largely consisted of curing childhood diseases. Measles, mumps, chicken pox -- these were definable ailments that would likely go away with proper treatment. Now, Dr. Jack Swanson, a pediatrician in Ames, Iowa, spends his days dealing with more elusive problems: depressed children, anorexic and bulimic teenagers, sexually precocious tweens, young substance abusers, younger perpetrators and victims of violence. In the heartland, on the East Coast and the West, America's 55,000 pediatricians are no longer just baby doctors dispensing inoculations, cough syrups and bromides. They have become de facto psychiatrists and subspecialists. They are child welfare advocates, conduits to other social services and navigators of byzantine H.M.O.'s. They are trench warriors in the battle against the ''new morbidity.''

headline.main: For Pediatricians, a Struggle Against the 'New Morbidity'

docs.abstract: Dr Marcia Sherman article offers guidelines for evaluating often conflicting results of medical studies (M)
docs.snippet: LATE at night, bathed in the glow of your computer screen, you hit the jackpot: three medical studies discussing the latest treatment for your spouse's snoring problem. But all arrive at different conclusions.    One is a case series published in a...
docs.lead_paragraph: LATE at night, bathed in the glow of your computer screen, you hit the jackpot: three medical studies discussing the latest treatment for your spouse's snoring problem. But all arrive at different conclusions. One is a case series published in a Scandinavian journal, the second is a study in the Annals of Sleep Apnea and the third is a large, randomized trial featured in the Journal of Medical Excellence. Which one should you believe? If you are going to peruse the medical Web sites, do you also need a hotline to a biostatistician, who can explain everything to you?

headline.main: Clinical Studies: Choosing Ones That Can Help

docs.abstract: Annie Lubliner Lehmann article on her lifelong history of dental problems; photos (M)
docs.snippet: PIECE by piece my body is being plundered by time. ''Wear and tear in exchange for experience and wisdom'' is my mother's reasoned thinking about the physical changes that accompany aging. And while I accept this with relative ease, I dispute the...
docs.lead_paragraph: PIECE by piece my body is being plundered by time. ''Wear and tear in exchange for experience and wisdom'' is my mother's reasoned thinking about the physical changes that accompany aging. And while I accept this with relative ease, I dispute the equation vigorously when it comes to teeth. Blessed with good genes, many people I know smile at themselves in their bathroom mirrors and see reflections of the same pebbly whites that broke through their swollen 6-year-old gums five decades before. They are like the teeth excavated by archaeologists that bit and chewed long before the toothbrush was invented, teeth so rich with detail they tell stories about culture right down to what, once upon a time, constituted an evening's meal.

headline.main: When Fillings Were in Favor: A Short History of My Teeth

docs.abstract: Article by Barbara Seaman, who has taken oral contraceptives for 40 years, discusses problem-plagued history of 'the pill'; photos (M)
docs.snippet: I AM not a scientist. I'm not a doctor. I've never been on the Pill. But the Pill and I have been going steady for 40 years, and I seem to have collected information about it that other old-timers either don't know or won't tell.
docs.lead_paragraph: I AM not a scientist. I'm not a doctor. I've never been on the Pill. But the Pill and I have been going steady for 40 years, and I seem to have collected information about it that other old-timers either don't know or won't tell.

headline.main: The Pill and I: 40 Years On, the Relationship Remains Wary
